topic.title: So, if the CIA is now framing QAnons by manipulating the news...
topic.body:
Does this mean their movement will have to shift directions entirely? Will it now break down into its primary components? The Trump supporters, the anti-illuminati folk, the anti-human trafficking folk, the anti-pedophilia folk, the white nationalists, the "woke" folk... That's all that was done... Q unified these groups into a solidarity because it helped all of these individuals' causes... Before Q, all these people belonged to these groups already... Think about it...

Oh, and as Trump said recently when he was questioned about his support for the QAnon Movement, "Is that a bad thing?" Is it bad that Q Unified the American People?

#FreeYourMind
#ViresEnNumeris

topic.title: We Are All Assange Now
topic.body:
#FreeJulianAssange
#MakeAmericaFreeAgain
#SheepNoMore

152 lawyers and 15 legal associations have signed a detailed and scathing open letter condemning what they describe as the denial of Julian Assange’s ‘right to a fair trial before the UK courts’.Mr Assange, the co-founder of WikiLeaks, remains incarcerated in Belmarsh maximum-security prison as he challenges his potential extradition to the United States to face spurious charges under the Espionage Act, for his role in publishing classified US documents.The letter was sent to Prime Minister Boris Johnson, as well as the Home Secretary, Secretary of State for Justice, and Foreign Minister on 14 August 2020, though it was only made public on 17 August.The signatories, which include the International Association of Democratic Lawyers and the Association of American Lawyers, point to the potential conflicts of interest which Chief Magistrate, Senior District Judge Emma Arbuthnot, who ruled against Mr Assange early on during the extradition process, failed to disclose.The case has since been taken over by Judge Vanessa Baraitser, though as Chief Magistrate Judge Arbuthnot remains responsible for overseeing proceedings in the Magistrates’ Courts. Lady Arbuthnot: ’has been shown to have financial links to institutions and individuals whose wrongdoings have been exposed by WikiLeaks, the organisation which Mr Assange founded. This seemingly clear conflict of interest was, however, not disclosed by the District Judge.’They also note that: ‘Mr Assange has been denied time and facilities to prepare his defence in violation of the principle of equality of arms which is inherent to the presumption of innocence and the rule of law.’The examples they give include: the inability of Mr Assange to be able to properly consult with his lawyers (most recently his lawyers have complained that it has been 17 weeks since they were able to consult properly with their client).Judge Baraitser’s refusal to permit Mr Assange to sit with his lawyers during the substantive hearings and the delay of months before the defendant was provided a laptop to review the thousands of documents in his case which, once finally provided by prison authorities, remains unsuitable for his needs.Judge Baraitser’s refusal to address Mr Assange’s alleged mistreatment is also singled out by the jurists. One key example is when prison authorities, ‘handcuffed him 11 times, placed him in 5 different cells, strip-searched him twice, and confiscated his privileged legal documents’.

The letter also warns that 17 out of 18 of the charges ‘violate the right to freedom of expression, the right to freedom of the press and the right to know’. Any prosecution and extradition based on the current indictment would ‘gravely endanger freedom of the press, a cornerstone of European democracies enshrined in Art. 10 of the [European Convention on Human Rights]’.

‘One of the most dangerous features of the Assange case is the idea that the US can seek to extradite any person, anywhere in the world, if they upset US interests.This extraterritorial reach is contrary to the rule of law and a dangerous attempt to undermine freedom of speech, a right all of us should cherish.’ said Former National President of the Australian Lawyers Alliance, Greg Barns who is among the signatories.Slovenian law Professor Andraž Teršek, who also signed the letter, argued that: ‘The case of Julian Assange is about political transparency, democratic legitimacy, free journalism and public media, which no individual should ever give up, and which no political institution, power or government should deny, prevent or punish. The trial’s implications are of great importance in modern society.’

Signatories of the letter also warned that Mr Assange faces cruel and unusual punishment in the US and note with concern the fact that the UN torture expert and two other medical experts have recorded that the publisher has exhibited clear symptoms of psychological torture.

The documents published by Mr Assange revealed, among other things, war crimes and other criminality committed by US-led forces in Iraq, Afghanistan and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. He faces up to 175 years in prison in the US if he is convicted on all of the charges in the indictment.

https://europeansworldwide.wordpress.com/2020/08/21/we-are-all-assange-now/

I mean, I have read all the comments to this point and I have no reason to believe otherwise. If you want to let the video tell you what to think, fine. But, it seems like even if it is a bunch of fake news, then the key takeaway would be how to perform a type of PsyOp/Disinformation Campaign. Just saying...

1598242145_1M8tVWMfjhezUzmRxrzyBaSiZc3Qb.body:
Well what I found odd about it was that the only reason I found out about QAnon is because someone I know told me the things I taught them about the Illuminati about 10 years ago seemed to be the same type of things the QAnons were trying to bring light to as well. Once I studied the Movement, I determined that it did just as I said, unified the American people and helped expose the evil in this country along with the supporters of the evil powers. However, I wouldn't call non-Q supporters "un-American," but rather that we hold different values on what is best for the future of the country. 

Now, if the anti-Q people did something unamerican, then I would be having some words with them. But, that is a seperate topic than the one I am trying to address. Is Q Anon bad?

Or, did it unite (let me rephrase this for you) a bunch of individuals that shared the same objectives? The adherants of Q's constantly said, "There's safety in numbers." Which is very true and also is Bitcoin's founding principle (Search info on SearX when you get a moment) for a fun fact lol. Now look back on ZeroNet where OTBTechnologies mentioned Q being Satoshi Nakamoto. Think about it.

It fascinating to ponder. No?

Back to the topic at hand though, should the QAnons find a new leader and remain as unified as possible or should they dissamble into their core components as is happening now while the CIA continues to frame them as terrorists?

> [adrenochrome](#comment_29_19dzDaMFcuCusp4anMUPkVc8zRzLJmxo9T): The most problematic part of the so called Q Movement is to educate it's followers to be passive: "Don't do anything, we (Q) will fight the deep state. Q is our savior." It's like a cult. So there is a high probability, that Q is just a CIA PsyOp. [...]

That's very observant of you. :)

In order to create a successful PSYOP the following must be established:

1    clearly define the mission so that it aligns with national objectives
2   need a PSYOP estimate of the situation
3    prepare the plan
4    media selection
5    product development
6    pretesting - determines the probable impact of the PSYOP on the target audience
 7   production and dissemination of PSYOP material
8    implementation
9    posttesting - evaluates audience responses
    feedback

Before these steps can occur, intelligence analysts must profile potential targets in order to determine which ones it would be most beneficial to target. In order to figure this out, analysts must determine the vulnerabilities of these groups and what they would be susceptible to. The analysts also determine the attitudes of the targets toward the current situation, their complaints, ethnic origin, frustrations, languages, problems, tensions, attitudes, motivations, and perceptions, and so on. Once the appropriate target(s) have been determined, the PSYOP can be created

PsyOps conducted on the American people would be illegal though unless done Anonymously and with plausible deniability (which is a term coined by the CIA refering to a legal defense they came up with which would (in theory) protect the US President from getting in trouble for their illegal activities that we came to realize were happening when the term was coined...)

https://nsarchive2.gwu.edu//NSAEBB/NSAEBB177/index.htm

Plausible denial involves the creation of power structures and chains of command loose and informal enough to be denied if necessary. The idea was that the CIA and later other bodies could be given controversial instructions by powerful figures, including the President himself, but that the existence and true source of those instructions could be denied if necessary if, for example, an operation went disastrously wrong and it was necessary for the administration to disclaim responsibility. 

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plausible_deniability

#PsyOp #PsychologicalOperations #Unethical
